Module Cryptography
Package cryptography.cracking

Class SpellChecker

java.lang.Object
cryptography.cracking.SpellChecker
public class SpellChecker
extends java.lang.Object
This class represents a spell checker. This class takes a text and analyses its potential mistakes based on semantic correctness. This correctness can be manipulated by adjusting a tolerance for consecutive consonants, which is interrupted by a vowel.

Idea

The idea is that, for a word to be pronounced fluently, there needs to be a number of vowels (e.g. 'aeiouy') interrupting a chain of consonants; Suppose we have the word 'crptgrph', which is very hard and unnatural to pronounce. But if we add some vowels, we get: 'cryptography', which is much easier to pronounce.

Example

We want to analyse a text in standard english. We first need to create an instance of SpellChecker:

SpellChecker spelling = new SpellChecker(myEnglishText);

Next, we have to specify the settings for our spell checker:

// vowels
spelling.setVowels("aeiou");

// number of consecutive consonants that are not counted as spelling mistakes
spelling.setConsonantTolerance(3);

// characters to exempt from consonant tolerance
spelling.setExcludes(" .;,:\n\t\r");

The number of potential spelling mistakes based on the above settings can now be calculated with the following method:

int mistakes = spelling.possibleMistakes();

    • getConsonantTolerance

      public int getConsonantTolerance()
      Returns the consonant tolerance. It is the number of consecutive consonants. If this number is exceeded, it is counted as a spelling mistake.
      Returns:
      The consonant tolerance

    • setConsonantTolerance

      public void setConsonantTolerance​(int consonantTolerance)
      Sets consonant tolerance. It is the number of consecutive consonants. If this number is exceeded, it is counted as a spelling mistake.
      Parameters:
      consonantTolerance - The consonant tolerance

      The vowels as a String
